elements.content: A series of new polynuclear complexes of divalent Ni and Cu with 2-cyano-2-oximino-acetic acid (later AACO2-) were obtained as the result of the ligand modification reaction in the process of complexation, using 2-cyano-2-oximino-acetates such as methyl- (later as MeCO), and ethyl- (as ECO later on). Synthesized compounds were characterized by spectroscopic methods, thermal analysis, magnetochemistry, and X-ray crystallography. Crystal data revealed the formation of the dimeric [Ni­(AACO)­(H2O)3]2­·H2O (1), trimeric K2[Ni3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2), and K2[Cu3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]·4H2O (3) complexes, with bridging NO-groups cyanoxime dianions. In the latter two compounds, the AACO2– anions adopt cis-arrangements around metal centers. One mononuclear complex of K2[Cu­(AACO)2­(H2O)]­·2H2O (4) composition was isolated and characterized as well, where the cyanoxime forms the trans-complex 4. There is moderate-to-strong antiferromagnetic coupling between metal centers in polynuclear complexes. Data of thermal analysis studies revealed high-energy properties for dehydrated complexes 3 and 4, which violently decompose at ∼200 °C. These compounds may be viewed as room temperature completely safe, but heat-triggered actuators, because of their pronounced mechanical action upon leaving the system (crucible). Final products of thermal decomposition are Ni and NiO for 1, and the mixture of NiO and K2O for 2, with metallic copper for 3 and 4.

Crystal data revealed the formation of the dimeric [Ni(AACO)(H2O)3]2⋅H2O (1), trimeric K2[Ni3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2), and K2[Cu3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (3) complexes, with bridging NO-groups cyanoxime dianions. In the latter two compounds, the AACO2- anions adopt cis-arrangements around metal centers. One mononuclear complex of K2[Cu(AACO)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O (4) composition was isolated and characterized as well, where the cyanoxime forms the trans-complex 4. These compounds may be viewed as room temperature completely safe, but heat-triggered actuators, because of their pronounced mechanical action upon leaving the system (crucible). Final products of thermal decomposition are Ni and NiO for 1, and the mixture of NiO and K2O for 2, with metallic copper for 3 and 4.

elements.content: A new in situ method for the synthesis of Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) complexes of 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-acetate dianion (AACO2−) was found. Previously, direct interaction between the H2AACO cyanoxime and its dianion did not lead to polymetallic complexes, which demonstrates the utility of this approach for synthetic coordination chemistry. The two copper­(II) complexes were found to have properties of high-energy compounds which violently decompose with release of a significant kinetic energy and formation of elemental Cu.

Thus, regardless of their sizeas big as homometallic (isopolyacids, for example), or heterometallic Keggin and Dawson heteropolyacids and their saltscompounds of A-type have distinct molecular structures with bridging oxo/hydroxo groups. This category of polymetallic compounds includes numerous Werner-type complexes and also organometallic clusters with metal–metal bonds. Polymers of B-type are predominantly homometallic compounds of different dimensionality.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

General classification of polymetallic coordination compounds is displayed in . Thus, regardless of their sizeas big as homometallic (isopolyacids, for example), or heterometallic Keggin and Dawson heteropolyacids and their saltscompounds of A-type have distinct molecular structures with bridging oxo/hydroxo groups. This category of polymetallic compounds includes numerous Werner-type complexes and also organometallic clusters with metal-metal bonds. Polymers of B-type are predominantly homometallic compounds of different dimensionality.

elements.clean_text: 1  Classification of Polymetallic Complexes with Their Most Commonly Thought Areas of Practical Application Shown on the Right      a A variety of bridging groups, as well as metallophilic interactions in 1D solids connect units into polymers.

elements.content:
A variety of bridging groups, as well as metallophilic interactions in 1D solids connect units into polymers.

Most polynuclear transition metals complexes demonstrate interesting magnetic properties, such as magnetic ordering, the most common antiferro- and ferro-magnetic type. It was discovered that some large polymetallic systems, such as Mn12 complexes, exhibit single-molecule magnets (SMMs) behavior, by slow relaxation of the magnetization at low temperatures. These SMMs can potentially be used as materials for quantum bits (qubits), because they exhibit quantum tunneling of magnetization, due to their small size and quantum phase interference. In such cases, the size of electronic devices and components will undergo desirable, and rather dramatic, miniaturization. However, the SMM systems have not been able to find applications in everyday electronics yet mainly due to their low operational temperatures. In those systems, the key organic ligand connecting metal centers was determined to be an oxime moiety acting as bridging groups. Several analogous oximes were employed to expand this class of interesting bridging ligands.

a A variety of bridging groups, as well as metallophilic interactions in 1D solids connect units into polymers.  

Most polynuclear transition metals complexes demonstrate interesting magnetic properties, such as magnetic ordering, the most common antiferro- and ferro-magnetic type. It was discovered that some large polymetallic systems, such as Mn12 complexes, exhibit single-molecule magnets (SMMs) behavior, by slow relaxation of the magnetization at low temperatures. These SMMs can potentially be used as materials for quantum bits (qubits), because they exhibit quantum tunneling of magnetization, due to their small size and quantum phase interference. In such cases, the size of electronic devices and components will undergo desirable, and rather dramatic, miniaturization. However, the SMM systems have not been able to find applications in everyday electronics yet mainly due to their low operational temperatures. In those systems, the key organic ligand connecting metal centers was determined to be an oxime moiety acting as bridging groups. Several analogous oximes were employed to expand this class of interesting bridging ligands.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of polynuclear oximate bridged metal complexes have been reported, using various preparative methods and ligand systems. The versatility in the coordination modes of oximes, coupled with conformational flexibility, made them very suitable anionic bridging groups in polynuclear coordination compounds which exhibit magnetic interaction. Some interesting peculiarities regarding structures of polymetallic oxime-based complexes and their magnetic behavior were found. Thus, in the work by Das, the β-aminoketoxime ligand of Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) ions complexes have been shown to be dimeric, with out-of-plane oximate bridging between the metal centers. The Ni­(II) complex showed weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the dimeric nickel centers, and the Cu­(II) complex showed weak ferromagnetic coupling between the Cu­(II) dimeric centers. Also, the bond distances of the bridging oxime groups were reported to have a significant effect on the magnetism of Ni­(II) polynuclear complexes of pyrazine-2-amidoxime, which displayed antiferromagnetic coupling. The antiferromagnetic exchange is occurring via the N–O bridging group of the oxime ligand. The N–O bond lengths of these complexes are shorter than 1.394 Å established critical bond lengths for effective exchange, and the Ni–N–O–Ni torsion angles are less than the determined critical angle of 75°, at which the antiferromagnetic coupling switches to the ferromagnetic one. The polydentate character of the oxime/nitroso groups, capable of a variety of binding modes to metal centers, is an essential feature for the formation of polynuclear complexes which demonstrate intense magnetic interactions. Several oximes-based ligands, which were found to support realization of multimetallic-core compounds, are shown in .

elements.clean_text: 2  Chemical Formulas of Oximes Used for Preparation of Polynuclear Transition Metal Complexes

elements.content: Cyanoximes represent a new subclass of low molecular weight oximes which have the general formula NC-C­(NOH)-R, with R being an electron withdrawing group. Contrary to classic ambidentate ligands, such as linear pseudohalogenides CN–, N3 –, NCO–, NCS–, NCTe–, and nitrite anion NO2 –, cyanoximes exemplify versatile ampolydentate ligands that have received intense development. There were only a few reported complexes of Cu and Ni with cyanoximes in general, with most of them being mononuclear compounds. With the exception of one dicopper, one stereospecific dinickel, and one octa-iron complex, no other homometallic or heterometallic complexes containing cyanoximes are reported.
elements.clean_text: Cyanoximes represent a new subclass of low molecular weight oximes which have the general formula NC-C(NOH)-R, with R being an electron withdrawing group. Contrary to classic ambidentate ligands, such as linear pseudohalogenides CN-, N3 -, NCO-, NCS-, NCTe-, and nitrite anion NO2 -, cyanoximes exemplify versatile ampolydentate ligands that have received intense development. There were only a few reported complexes of Cu and Ni with cyanoximes in general, with most of them being mononuclear compounds. With the exception of one dicopper, one stereospecific dinickel, and one octa-iron complex, no other homometallic or heterometallic complexes containing cyanoximes are reported.

elements.content: The 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-ethyl acetate, which is commercially known as “Oxyma” (HECO), and its analogous compound 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-methyl acetate (HMeCO) represent inexpensive and easily accessible compounds. We report the synthesis and properties of unusual Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) complexes that contain the 2-hydroxyimino-2-cyano-acetate dianion (AACO2–), which originates via selective base-catalyzed hydrolysis of ester-cyanoximes HECO and HMeCO by divalent transition metal ions. Presented in this paper are the polynuclear complexes of the latter two transition metal ions, which are inaccessible from the AACO2– dianion, but can be readily available from starting cyanoxime esters.

Presented in this paper are the polynuclear complexes of the latter two transition metal ions, which are inaccessible from the AACO2- dianion, but can be readily available from starting cyanoxime esters.

Two modified and optimized procedures for the synthesis of ligands are presented below, while two-step method of synthesis of metal complexes is shown in .

Red and blue atoms in the initial compounds indicate the core for the formation of oxamide as a product of incomplete hydrolysis of cyanoxime esters.

Preparation of HMeCO and HECO Cyanoxime Ligands

The 2-cyano-2-(hydroxyimino) methyl acetate (later HMeCO) was obtained according to the reaction below: NC ‐ CH 2 ‐ C ( O ) OCH 3 + CH 3 COOH + NaNO 2 → ∼ 50 ° C NC ‐ C (  N ‐ OH ) ‐ C ( O ) OCH 3 + CH 3 COONa HMeCO

elements.content: Glacial acetic acid (100 mL) and NaOH pellets (12 g) were placed in a 500 mL three-neck round-bottom flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer and a long stem funnel, under intense stirring. Within ∼10 min, pellets of hydroxide dissolved, evolving heat and bringing the mixture to reflux. Methyl cyanoacetate (50.0 g, 0.50 mol) was added to this hot solution, and slow dropwise addition of a solution of NaNO2 (80 g, 1.16 mol) in water (100 mL) began immediately. The addition was complete within 1–1.5 h, but the stirring continued until the reaction mixture temperature dropped to ∼+25 °C, and then continued for an additional 3 h, until the precipitate of the cyanoxime began to form. Then the mixture was diluted with water (100 mL) and allowed to stand at +4 °C for another 3 h. Bulk solid precipitate was collected by vacuum filtration and dried in air to give microcrystalline off-white product. Yield: ∼90%.

elements.content: Target cyanoxime ligand was prepared by reacting 5.700 g (82.6 mM) of NaNO2 dissolved in 75 mL of H2O with 10.000 g (88.4 mM) of ethyl cyanoacetate in a round-bottom flask, according to the reaction in . Then 3.6 mL of 1 M H3PO4 was added to the reaction mixture, dropwise over 45 min, and the temperature was kept at +3–4 °C using an ice bath. After the addition of 1 M H3PO4 was completed, the temperature was raised to +40 °C, and the reaction was quenched with 7.3 mL of fuming HCl at +65 °C. The mixture was left to cool to room temperature. The reaction mixture was then kept in the refrigerator for a period of approximately 11 h. The mixture was filtered using filter paper and gravity filtration. The precipitate was dried in a vacuum. The filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate after the mixture was treated with solid NaCl to facilitate extraction. The solution was off-yellow, and the color was maintained in the organic phase, while the aqueous phase was colorless. The dried precipitate was 7.153 g. An additional amount of 3.042 g was obtained after the extraction. The total yield of HECO was 10.195 g (81%); m.p = 129.4–132.4 °C.

elements.content:
GC-MS data: t R = 7.20 min.

Mass-spectrometry data: m/z = 142 (M+•), 125 (M–OH), 114 (M-CH2CH2), 97 (M-OCH2CH3), 69 (M-CO2CH2CH3).

Preparation of Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) Complexes from the HMeCO Ligand

Two solutions of HMeCO were prepared separately in two 25 mL beakers by dissolving 0.300 g (2.34 mmol) of the HMeCO ligand in 5 mL of H2O. Then 2.34 mL (2.34 mmol) of 1 M KOH solution was added to each of the HMeCO solutions in the beakers for the deprotonation of the HMeCO ligand (). The color of the solution changed to deep yellow. The solutions were stirred continuously using magnetic stirrers. Then 0.341 g (1.17 mmol) of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.1870 g (1.17 mmol) of CuSO4·5H2O were dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water in another two separate beakers, and these solutions were added in, dropwise, to the separate beakers containing the deprotonated MECO– ligand solutions, using a Pasteur pipet. Clear, deep brown solution was formed in the beaker to which the Ni­(II) salt was added, and clear green solution was formed in the beaker to which the Cu­(II) salt was added. The solutions were allowed to stand for ca. 2 h, under continuous stirring, at room temperature. The clear deep brown solution and green solutions were filtered, through a Pasteur pipet packed with glass wools, into clear polyethylene tubes. The filtrates were kept in a desiccator charged with concentrated H2SO4 for almost two months, to provide slow growth of colored crystals suitable for the X-ray analysis quality. In this way, complexes K2[Ni3(AACO)4·(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2) and K2[Cu­(AACO)2­·H2O]­·2H2O (4) were obtained. Also, a rather significant amount of colorless large crystals (around ∼20%!), which turned out to be of oxamide [H2NC­(O)]2, was collected and analyzed. Both metal complexes and organic diamide are products of hydrolysis of the initial HMeCO ester.

elements.content: Two separate solutions of HECO were prepared separately, in two 25 mL beakers, by dissolving 0.300 g (2.11 mmol) of the HECO ligand in 5 mL of H2O. Then 2.11 mL (2.11 mmol) of 1 M KOH solution was added to each of the HECO solutions in the beakers for the deprotonation of the HECO ligand (). The color of the solution changed to deep yellow. The solutions were stirred continuously using magnetic stirrers. Then 0.3069 g (1.06 mM) of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.1685 g (1.06 mmol) of CuSO4·5H2O, were dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water in another two separate beakers, and these solutions were added in, dropwise, separately to the beakers containing the deprotonated ECO– ligand solutions. A clear deep brown solution was formed in the beaker to which the Ni­(II) salt was added, and green solution was formed in the beaker to which the Cu­(II) salt was added. The solutions were allowed to stand for ∼2 h, under continuous stirring at room temperature. No precipitates were formed. The clear deep brown solution and green solutions were filtered through a tight glass wool plug into clear 10 mL capacity polyethylene test tubes where crystals eventually appeared in abundance. For future convenient identification and use of the obtained metal complexes, we refer to , which contains compounds’ abbreviations employed in this paper. We did not feel the necessity of obtaining their elemental composition data since all characterization of the obtained four metal complexes as well as one the initial cyanoxime ligands (HECO) and the side reaction product oxamide was done using those crystalline samples structures of which have been determined. All other investigationsspectroscopic, magnetochemical and thermogravimetricwere conducted from the same well-crystallized specimen (see Supporting Information SI 1, 2).

Safety note: handling of copper­(II) complexes in general should be careful since it is known that in the 2+ oxidation state it is a mild oxidizer of organic compounds. Moreover, we discovered in current work that synthesized polynuclear copper­(II) complexes represent high-energy compounds after some heat activation. No shock sensitivity tests were performed! Therefore, preparation and handling of these complexes should be done with appropriate care with the amounts not exceeding 250 mg.
elements.clean_text: Safety note: handling of copper(II) complexes in general should be careful since it is known that in the 2+ oxidation state it is a mild oxidizer of organic compounds. Moreover, we discovered in current work that synthesized polynuclear copper(II) complexes represent high-energy compounds after some heat activation. No shock sensitivity tests were performed! Therefore, preparation and handling of these complexes should be done with appropriate care with the amounts not exceeding 250 mg.

elements.content: The IR spectra of the initial compounds and complexes were recorded on a Bruker FT-IR Vertex 70 spectrophotometer, in 13 mm diameter KBr pellets, at room temperature, using 64 repetitions with 4 cm–1 resolution. All spectra were compensated for background, to minimize moisture and CO2 appearance. The UV–visible spectra were recorded for solid samples of complexes using diffuse reflectance technique (SDR), with the aid of a Labsphere accessory to Cary 100-Bio spectrophotometer, operating from 200 to 850 nm (SI 3). A sample of fine powder of MgO was used as calibration standard.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Methods, Instrumentation

Spectroscopy

The IR spectra of the initial compounds and complexes were recorded on a Bruker FT-IR Vertex 70 spectrophotometer, in 13 mm diameter KBr pellets, at room temperature, using 64 repetitions with 4 cm-1 resolution. All spectra were compensated for background, to minimize moisture and CO2 appearance. The UV-visible spectra were recorded for solid samples of complexes using diffuse reflectance technique (SDR), with the aid of a Labsphere accessory to Cary 100-Bio spectrophotometer, operating from 200 to 850 nm (SI 3). A sample of fine powder of MgO was used as calibration standard.

elements.content: The TG analysis was performed on the TA Instrument Q-600, in an alumina crucible, under pure nitrogen flow, in the range between 30–1000 °C at 100 ± 2 mL/min, and a heating rate ranging from 1 to 20 °C/min, depending on a sample behavior. The crucible was calcined prior to each experiment, using the propane torch. Data of the TG analyses were processed using the TA Universal Analysis software package.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The TG analysis was performed on the TA Instrument Q-600, in an alumina crucible, under pure nitrogen flow, in the range between 30-1000 °C at 100 ± 2 mL/min, and a heating rate ranging from 1 to 20 °C/min, depending on a sample behavior. The crucible was calcined prior to each experiment, using the propane torch. Data of the TG analyses were processed using the TA Universal Analysis software package.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2–300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.5 T, on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1–4, with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID susceptometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holders previously measured, using the same conditions, and for the diamagnetic contributions of the salt, as deduced by using Pascaĺs constant tables.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2-300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.5 T, on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1-4, with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID susceptometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holders previously measured, using the same conditions, and for the diamagnetic contributions of the salt, as deduced by using Pascaĺs constant tables.

elements.content: The crystal structures were determined for all four compounds presented in this work: [Ni­(AACO)­(H2O)3]2­·H2O (1), K2[Ni3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2), K2[Cu3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (3), and K2[Cu­(AACO)2­(H2O)]­·2H2O (4). Selected crystals of these complexes were mounted on a thin glass fiber, or placed into the CryoLoop, and then attached to the copper pin positioned on the goniometer head of the Bruker APEX2 diffractometer, equipped with a SMART CCD area detector. The data sets were measured at low temperatures. The intensity data were collected in ω scan mode, using the Mo tube (Kα radiation; λ = 0.71073 Å) with a highly oriented graphite monochromator. The intensities were integrated from four series’ of 364 exposures each, covering 0.5° in ω at 10–60 s of exposure time, with the total data set being a sphere for both wavelengths. The space group determination was done with the aid of XPREP software. The absorption correction was performed, using values from face-indexed crystals and numerical values obtained from the set of images recorded with the video-microscope (SI 4, 5), followed by the SADABS program that was included in the Bruker AXS software package. All structures were solved by direct methods, and refined by least-squares on weighted F 2 values for all reflections, using the SHELXTL program. The structures reported herein metal complexes did not have apparent errors and are well refined with their checkCIF reports shown in SI 6. Crystal and refinement data can be found in , while selected and bond lengths and angles which are important for discussion are listed in . Drawing the crystal structures and packing diagrams was done using the ORTEP 3v2 and Mercury software packages. Thermal ellipsoids in all figures are drawn at their 50% probability level. All four crystal structures have been deposited into the CCDC under the following numbers: 1473520 (1), 1473524 (2), 1473518 (3), and 1473523 (4). Crystal structures of the two organic compounds were deposited as well: HECO – 1473516, oxamide – 1473522. The PLATON checkCIF reports for all structures are shown at the end of Supporting Information SI 33–40.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystal structures were determined for all four compounds presented in this work: [Ni(AACO)(H2O)3]2⋅H2O (1), K2[Ni3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2), K2[Cu3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (3), and K2[Cu(AACO)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O (4). Selected crystals of these complexes were mounted on a thin glass fiber, or placed into the CryoLoop, and then attached to the copper pin positioned on the goniometer head of the Bruker APEX2 diffractometer, equipped with a SMART CCD area detector. The data sets were measured at low temperatures. The intensity data were collected in ω scan mode, using the Mo tube (Kα radiation; λ = 0.71073 Å) with a highly oriented graphite monochromator. The intensities were integrated from four series' of 364 exposures each, covering 0.5° in ω at 10-60 s of exposure time, with the total data set being a sphere for both wavelengths. The space group determination was done with the aid of XPREP software. The absorption correction was performed, using values from face-indexed crystals and numerical values obtained from the set of images recorded with the video-microscope (SI 4, 5), followed by the SADABS program that was included in the Bruker AXS software package. All structures were solved by direct methods, and refined by least-squares on weighted F  2  values for all reflections, using the SHELXTL program. The structures reported herein metal complexes did not have apparent errors and are well refined with their checkCIF reports shown in SI 6. Crystal and refinement data can be found in , while selected and bond lengths and angles which are important for discussion are listed in . Drawing the crystal structures and packing diagrams was done using the ORTEP 3v2 and Mercury software packages. Thermal ellipsoids in all figures are drawn at their 50% probability level. All four crystal structures have been deposited into the CCDC under the following numbers: 1473520 (1), 1473524 (2), 1473518 (3), and 1473523 (4). Crystal structures of the two organic compounds were deposited as well: HECO - 1473516, oxamide - 1473522. The PLATON checkCIF reports for all structures are shown at the end of Supporting Information SI 33-40.

Preparation of nonpolymeric, molecular complexes of A-type () is typically accomplished as a result of condensation reaction where oxide atoms O2– in acid residues of vanadic, molybdic, tungstic acids, for example, are substituted with EO4 2– (E = Mo, W, or V) residue to form either isopoly- or heteropolyacids. One of the examples of such condensations is dimerization of CrO4 2– anion in acidic media with the formation of dichromate Cr2O7 2– anion. At first, polymetallic/polynuclear transition metals complexes, that were found to have unusual magnetic properties including SMM, were obtained by accident when involved in the preparation organic ligands were hydrolyzed. As the result, complexes contained bridging μ-hydroxo- μ-alkoxo-groups, μ-oxo atoms, as well as the mixture of anionic and neutral organic ligands and generated structures possessed a wide range of complexity. Specifically for the oximes-containing complexes examples are Cu3-, Cu27- Ni6-, Mn15- polymetallic core as well as coexistence of HL/L– moieties. Conventionally used aliphatic and aromatic mono- and dioximes are weak organic acids with pK a values above 10, and their ability to form chelate knots frequently is not sufficient for the complex formation. Hence, often for the increase of oximes’ nucleophilicity and their reactivity toward metal centers the deprotonation is required. However, anionic oximes in typically dilute aqueous solutions L– generate back protonated HL species: L– + H2O = HL + OH–. As the result, more negative charges are required to compensate for a rather significant cumulative positive charge on the metallic core. These counteranions usually are OH–, O2–, OR–, or other groups such as, for instance, azide anions. The amount of these auxiliary groups in the mixed-ligands complexes varies considerably depending on the nature of the oxime used. In the work reported herein we observed a unique situation when cyanoximes monoanions of carboxylic esters MeCO– and ECO– upon de-esterification generated dianions of the 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-acetic acid AACO2– and in that way completely alleviated the necessity of presence of other auxiliary groups to compensate positive charge of metal centers in polynuclear complexes.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses of Polynuclear Complexes

Preparation of nonpolymeric, molecular complexes of A-type () is typically accomplished as a result of condensation reaction where oxide atoms O2- in acid residues of vanadic, molybdic, tungstic acids, for example, are substituted with EO4 2- (E = Mo, W, or V) residue to form either isopoly- or heteropolyacids. One of the examples of such condensations is dimerization of CrO4 2- anion in acidic media with the formation of dichromate Cr2O7 2- anion. At first, polymetallic/polynuclear transition metals complexes, that were found to have unusual magnetic properties including SMM, were obtained by accident when involved in the preparation organic ligands were hydrolyzed. As the result, complexes contained bridging μ-hydroxo- μ-alkoxo-groups, μ-oxo atoms, as well as the mixture of anionic and neutral organic ligands and generated structures possessed a wide range of complexity. Specifically for the oximes-containing complexes examples are Cu3-, Cu27- Ni6-, Mn15- polymetallic core as well as coexistence of HL/L- moieties. Conventionally used aliphatic and aromatic mono- and dioximes are weak organic acids with pK a values above 10, and their ability to form chelate knots frequently is not sufficient for the complex formation. Hence, often for the increase of oximes' nucleophilicity and their reactivity toward metal centers the deprotonation is required. However, anionic oximes in typically dilute aqueous solutions L- generate back protonated HL species: L- + H2O = HL + OH-. As the result, more negative charges are required to compensate for a rather significant cumulative positive charge on the metallic core. These counteranions usually are OH-, O2-, OR-, or other groups such as, for instance, azide anions. The amount of these auxiliary groups in the mixed-ligands complexes varies considerably depending on the nature of the oxime used. In the work reported herein we observed a unique situation when cyanoximes monoanions of carboxylic esters MeCO- and ECO- upon de-esterification generated dianions of the 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-acetic acid AACO2- and in that way completely alleviated the necessity of presence of other auxiliary groups to compensate positive charge of metal centers in polynuclear complexes.

elements.content: Cyano-hydroxyimino-acetic acid (H2AACO) was reported to be an alkaline hydrolytic degradation product of cymoxanila fungicide to control late blight in plants. Further degradation of the H2AACO led to the formation of oxalic acid. This degradation was reported to be pH and temperature dependent, with the rate for the degradation higher in acidic pH. Metal ions have been shown to influence the rate of hydrolysis of organic compounds where some these reactions show pH dependence and others do not. Some of these reactions represent metal ion promoted OH– and H+ catalyzing hydrolysis of esters. The promotion effect of divalent metal ion in the OH– hydrolysis of esters has been reported to have the rate enhanced up to 90–109 times. Typically, metal ion promoted OH– catalyzed reactions have been observed in ester hydrolysis reaction, when there is a functional group present in the ester which will allow strong interaction with the metal ions that will lead to chelation. This can also be favored by using high metal-to-ligand ratios. Nucleophilic attack of the OH– is made easy due to the polarization of the carbonyl oxygen by metal ions. The catalysis of nucleophilic organic reactions by metal ions has been a subject of interest, due to their possible correlations with biological systems, where they have a role in the mechanism of hydrolytic metalloenzymes, e.g., carboxypeptidase A with a Zn2+ at the active site, where metal ion may be coordinated to the carbonyl of the ester and the amide substrate where the Zn2+ coordination polarizes the carbonyl group of the substrate, thereby increasing its susceptibility to nucleophilic attack. The majority of the metal complexes formed after these hydrolysis reactions are mononuclear. Malek et al. (2004) did some experimental and theoretical calculations on the H2AACO oxime, in order to understand their coordination to metal ions, and Sliva et al. (1998) studied the Cu­(II) and the Ni­(II) complexes of prepared pure H2AACO, with successes in obtaining the monomeric Cu­(II) and Ni­(II), as well as only one dimeric Cu­(II) (pH > 5) complex of the AACO2–dianion reported thus far. In our case, the Ni­(II) complexes, made in situ with metal ion catalyzed hydrolysis of the 2-cyano-hydroxyimino acetic acid ethyl ester (HECO) and 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-acetic acid methyl ester (HMeCO), are dinuclear and trinuclear crystallohydrate metal complexes. In the case of the Cu­(II)-MeCO– system, there are trinuclear and mononuclear crystallohydrate metal complexes. A similar situation occurred in the past, during an attempt to prepare Pd and Pt complexes with the amide-cyanoxime ACO– anion. The overall hydrolysis process for both employed ester-cyanoximes is depicted in . The trinuclear Ni­(II) complex K2[Ni3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2) and the trinuclear Cu­(II) complex K2[Cu3(AACO)4­·(H2O)4]­·4H2O (3) were found to be isostructural (; and ).

Syntheses of Cyanoximes Carboxylic Esters and Their Hydrolysis Reactions

Cyano-hydroxyimino-acetic acid (H2AACO) was reported to be an alkaline hydrolytic degradation product of cymoxanila fungicide to control late blight in plants. Further degradation of the H2AACO led to the formation of oxalic acid. This degradation was reported to be pH and temperature dependent, with the rate for the degradation higher in acidic pH. Metal ions have been shown to influence the rate of hydrolysis of organic compounds where some these reactions show pH dependence and others do not. Some of these reactions represent metal ion promoted OH-  and H+  catalyzing hydrolysis of esters. The promotion effect of divalent metal ion in the OH- hydrolysis of esters has been reported to have the rate enhanced up to 90-109 times. Typically, metal ion promoted OH- catalyzed reactions have been observed in ester hydrolysis reaction, when there is a functional group present in the ester which will allow strong interaction with the metal ions that will lead to chelation. This can also be favored by using high metal-to-ligand ratios. Nucleophilic attack of the OH- is made easy due to the polarization of the carbonyl oxygen by metal ions. The catalysis of nucleophilic organic reactions by metal ions has been a subject of interest, due to their possible correlations with biological systems, where they have a role in the mechanism of hydrolytic metalloenzymes, e.g., carboxypeptidase A with a Zn2+ at the active site, where metal ion may be coordinated to the carbonyl of the ester and the amide substrate where the Zn2+ coordination polarizes the carbonyl group of the substrate, thereby increasing its susceptibility to nucleophilic attack. The majority of the metal complexes formed after these hydrolysis reactions are mononuclear. Malek et al. (2004) did some experimental and theoretical calculations on the H2AACO oxime, in order to understand their coordination to metal ions, and Sliva et al. (1998) studied the Cu(II) and the Ni(II) complexes of prepared pure H2AACO, with successes in obtaining the monomeric Cu(II) and Ni(II), as well as only one dimeric Cu(II) (pH > 5) complex of the AACO2-dianion reported thus far. In our case, the Ni(II) complexes, made in situ with metal ion catalyzed hydrolysis of the 2-cyano-hydroxyimino acetic acid ethyl ester (HECO) and 2-cyano-2-hydroxyimino-acetic acid methyl ester (HMeCO), are dinuclear and trinuclear crystallohydrate metal complexes. In the case of the Cu(II)-MeCO- system, there are trinuclear and mononuclear crystallohydrate metal complexes. A similar situation occurred in the past, during an attempt to prepare Pd and Pt complexes with the amide-cyanoxime ACO- anion. The overall hydrolysis process for both employed ester-cyanoximes is depicted in . The trinuclear Ni(II) complex K2[Ni3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2) and the trinuclear Cu(II) complex K2[Cu3(AACO)4⋅(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (3) were found to be isostructural (;  and ).

elements.content: Another peculiar feature of these ester-cyanoximes/transition metals/water systems is the persistent formation of significant quantities of oxamide, [C­(O)­NH2]2. Oxamide crystals were always obtained as a side product from the syntheses of these polynuclear complexes, as depicted in , above. When we used Zn2+ cations, the result was the same, with respect to the oxamide formation, which highlights indifference of the hydrolysis products from 3d transition metal ions present in the system. A pathway was proposed for the formation of oxamide, but the mechanism for the formation of this side product is yet to be fully elucidated. Nevertheless, it has been known for a long time that nitriles undergo stepwise hydrolysis to carboxylic acids (their ammonium salts to be exact) via formation of amides. However, the formation of the amide from the oxime moiety represents Beckman rearrangement which takes place at acidic conditions. These were inconsistent with our particular reaction conditions during preparations of complexes carried out at room temperature in aqueous solutions. More studies, including 13C, 15N isotopic labeling, are needed to elucidate the mechanisms of these rather unusual transformations in aqueous solutions, which end up in a partial hydrolysis of involved groups to the amide, instead of the carboxylic acid and its ammonium salt.

elements.content: As we stated in the synthesis section above, no precipitates were formed upon mixing of ingredients. The clear deep brown solution and green solutions were filtered through a tight glass wool plug into clear 10 mL capacity polyethylene test tubes where crystals eventually appeared in abundance. Thus, filtrates were kept in those tubes in a desiccator charged with concentrated H2SO4 for quite some time until high quality crystals slowly grew up on walls of tubes (SI 1,2). It is important to note that the use of glass tubes and beakers for crystallization purposes did not lead to suitable crystals at all, but plastic tubes with the hydrophobic surface were the correct choice for a good quality specimen. Wettability of a glass surface with aqueous solutions leads to the formation of poor quality frost-like crystals “crawling” down the concaved surface of solution during water evaporation. Numerous microcrystals that formed during such event represented multiple seeds that prevented the formation of well-shaped large crystals (SI 1,2). At the same time nonwettable by aqueous solution smooth walls of plastic tubes had convex surface, and this facilitated upon water evaporation slow growth of a good quality much larger crystals. Another good feature of the use of plastic tubes for crystal growth from aqueous solutions is much easier and essentially nondestructive removal of crystalline specimen from the tubes. Along with colored crystals of transition metals complexes, large, well-shaped colorless prisms of the oxamide were also formed. The actual yield of this compound varied between 15 to ∼26%. Again, it turned out that the metal-containing products of these preparations were Cu­(II) and Ni­(II) complexes of AACO2– dianion and oxamide, NH2C­(O)-C­(O)­NH2. Both resulted from the hydrolysis of the starting HMeCO and HECO cyanoximes.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Growth

As we stated in the synthesis section above, no precipitates were formed upon mixing of ingredients. The clear deep brown solution and green solutions were filtered through a tight glass wool plug into clear 10 mL capacity polyethylene test tubes where crystals eventually appeared in abundance. Thus, filtrates were kept in those tubes in a desiccator charged with concentrated H2SO4 for quite some time until high quality crystals slowly grew up on walls of tubes (SI 1,2). It is important to note that the use of glass tubes and beakers for crystallization purposes did not lead to suitable crystals at all, but plastic tubes with the hydrophobic surface were the correct choice for a good quality specimen. Wettability of a glass surface with aqueous solutions leads to the formation of poor quality frost-like crystals "crawling" down the concaved surface of solution during water evaporation. Numerous microcrystals that formed during such event represented multiple seeds that prevented the formation of well-shaped large crystals (SI 1,2). At the same time nonwettable by aqueous solution smooth walls of plastic tubes had convex surface, and this facilitated upon water evaporation slow growth of a good quality much larger crystals. Another good feature of the use of plastic tubes for crystal growth from aqueous solutions is much easier and essentially nondestructive removal of crystalline specimen from the tubes. Along with colored crystals of transition metals complexes, large, well-shaped colorless prisms of the oxamide were also formed. The actual yield of this compound varied between 15 to ~26%. Again, it turned out that the metal-containing products of these preparations were Cu(II) and Ni(II) complexes of AACO2- dianion and oxamide, NH2C(O)-C(O)NH2. Both resulted from the hydrolysis of the starting HMeCO and HECO cyanoximes.

elements.content: The X-ray analysis showed that the ECO– anions in the presence of metal ions were hydrolyzed with the generation of the AACO2– dianion. The Ni­(II) ion in emerald-green complex of AACO2– is a bimetallic tricyclic complex, with one water molecule outside the coordination sphere (). The crystal and refinement data for this complex are displayed in , while selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . All H atoms during structure solution and refinement of 1 were found on the electron density map, and refined isotropically. The AACO2– dianions are bound to nickel centers in chelate fashion, using the nitrogen atoms of the oximes and the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group. Also, the AACO2– dianion acts as a bridge, connecting two Ni centers via N–O bond. Thus, two nickel atoms are bridged in a μ2-fashion by the NO group of the AACO2–, making a six-membered metallacycle system with the two nickel centers opposite to each other. The AACO2– moieties occupy the equatorial position, coordinating in a trans-anti-configuration (oxime group trans to the carbonyl group). The axial positions around the Ni­(II) ions are each occupied by two water molecules trans to each other, and an equatorial position is occupied by another water molecule, creating a distorted octahedral environment around the Ni­(II) ion (). The vacant positions in the equatorial plane are occupied by bridging O atoms ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

[Ni(AACO)(H2O)3]2⋅H2O (1)

The X-ray analysis showed that the ECO- anions in the presence of metal ions were hydrolyzed with the generation of the AACO2- dianion. The Ni(II) ion in emerald-green complex of AACO2- is a bimetallic tricyclic complex, with one water molecule outside the coordination sphere (). The crystal and refinement data for this complex are displayed in , while selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . All H atoms during structure solution and refinement of 1 were found on the electron density map, and refined isotropically. The AACO2- dianions are bound to nickel centers in chelate fashion, using the nitrogen atoms of the oximes and the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group. Also, the AACO2- dianion acts as a bridge, connecting two Ni centers via N-O bond. Thus, two nickel atoms are bridged in a μ2-fashion by the NO group of the AACO2-, making a six-membered metallacycle system with the two nickel centers opposite to each other. The AACO2- moieties occupy the equatorial position, coordinating in a trans-anti-configuration (oxime group trans to the carbonyl group). The axial positions around the Ni(II) ions are each occupied by two water molecules trans to each other, and an equatorial position is occupied by another water molecule, creating a distorted octahedral environment around the Ni(II) ion (). The vacant positions in the equatorial plane are occupied by bridging O atoms ().

elements.content: There is also a noncoordinated water molecule that acts as a linker between units of the complex 1. In the unit cell, the water molecules from each [Ni­(AACO)­(H2O)3]2­·H2O occupy channels extending along the b-direction (SI 7, 8). The inversion center is in the middle of the Ni–N–O–Ni ring (). The shortest Ni···Ni distance is 3.776 Å, which is much greater than the normal metal–metal bond. Geometry details of the distorted [NiO5N] octahedron are shown in . Hydrogen bonding is essential in the packing of this complex into a crystal and is shown in SI 9. It joins dimeric units of 1 into 3D network. Noncoordinated water molecules O7w are occupying channels running along the b-direction in the unit cell. Complex 1 is not isostructural to the Cu-complex of the same composition (SI 10) reported earlier.

elements.content: The reaction of the HMeCO ligand in the presence of KOH and Ni­(II) salt leads to hydrolysis of the HMeCO ligand yielding the AACO2– dianion. The compound crystallized as fine thin light-green plates of the trimetallic complex with AACO2– dianions. The crystal and refinement data for the complex are shown in . Selected bond lengths and angles for this structure are summarized in . There are two types of Ni­(II) centers in this complex: one with the coordination number five (Ni1), and one six-coordinated (Ni2) (SI 11, 12). The Ni1 has two AACO2– dianions, coordinated using the nitrogen atom of the oxime and oxygen atom of the carboxylate group to form a five-membered metallacycle. These nickel centers have an axial water molecule, thereby creating a square-based, pyramidal environment. There is, however, longer electrostatic contact to this metal center from O3 atoms from the carboxylate group of the closest neighboring molecule (SI 13). The Ni2 center has four oxygen atoms from four N–O groups of four oximes in the equatorial positions, bridging it with the Ni1 centers. There are also two trans axial water molecules, creating an octahedral configuration around the Ni­(II) center (). The coordination mode of the AACO2– ion to the Ni1 centers is in trans-anti-configurations and the ligand moieties, coordinating oppositely to the nickel centers, are cis to each other. The ligand displays two coordinating modes: chelating (κ2), and bridging (μ2). The overall structure of the complex at the Ni1 center is cis (). The basal distances around Ni1 (in the range 1.947–1.980 Å, ) are shorter than the apical one (2.254 Å) and confirm that the environment around Ni1 is a slightly distorted square-base pyramid (SI 13). The equatorial bond lengths around Ni2 (1.960(4) and 1.977(4) Å) are also shorter than the axial ones (2.254(5) Å) and show that the environment of the Ni2 is an elongated octahedron (SI 12). The metal ion is in a special position (inversion center) with SOF = 0.5. These two nickel centers (Ni1 and Ni2) are not on the same plane (SI 14). The dihedral angle of the basal and equatorial planes is 26.11° (.B). Neither of the two Ni1 centers are on the same plane, but are on fairly parallel planes, with an offset of 1.288 Å (SI 14). There are also two potassium counterions, surrounded by four water molecules. The potassium ions have electrostatic interactions with the carboxylate oxygen, carbonyl oxygen, oxygen atoms of the water molecules, as well as longer contacts with nitrile groups. The nitrile groups are practically linear; the N4–C5–C4 and N2–C2–C1 bond angles are 177.3° and 178.1°, respectively. Extensive and rather complex H-bonding between H2O molecules both coordination water to Ni-centers and outer-sphere crystallization water plays an essential role in organization of the structure (SI 15).
elements.clean_text:
K2[Ni3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2)

The reaction of the HMeCO ligand in the presence of KOH and Ni(II) salt leads to hydrolysis of the HMeCO ligand yielding the AACO2- dianion. The compound crystallized as fine thin light-green plates of the trimetallic complex with AACO2- dianions. The crystal and refinement data for the complex are shown in . Selected bond lengths and angles for this structure are summarized in . There are two types of Ni(II) centers in this complex: one with the coordination number five (Ni1), and one six-coordinated (Ni2) (SI 11, 12). The Ni1 has two AACO2- dianions, coordinated using the nitrogen atom of the oxime and oxygen atom of the carboxylate group to form a five-membered metallacycle. These nickel centers have an axial water molecule, thereby creating a square-based, pyramidal environment. There is, however, longer electrostatic contact to this metal center from O3 atoms from the carboxylate group of the closest neighboring molecule (SI 13). The Ni2 center has four oxygen atoms from four N-O groups of four oximes in the equatorial positions, bridging it with the Ni1 centers. There are also two trans axial water molecules, creating an octahedral configuration around the Ni(II) center (). The coordination mode of the AACO2- ion to the Ni1 centers is in trans-anti-configurations and the ligand moieties, coordinating oppositely to the nickel centers, are cis to each other. The ligand displays two coordinating modes: chelating (κ2), and bridging (μ2). The overall structure of the complex at the Ni1 center is cis (). The basal distances around Ni1 (in the range 1.947-1.980 Å, ) are shorter than the apical one (2.254 Å) and confirm that the environment around Ni1 is a slightly distorted square-base pyramid (SI 13). The equatorial bond lengths around Ni2 (1.960(4) and 1.977(4) Å) are also shorter than the axial ones (2.254(5) Å) and show that the environment of the Ni2 is an elongated octahedron (SI 12). The metal ion is in a special position (inversion center) with SOF = 0.5. These two nickel centers (Ni1 and Ni2) are not on the same plane (SI 14). The dihedral angle of the basal and equatorial planes is 26.11° (.B). Neither of the two Ni1 centers are on the same plane, but are on fairly parallel planes, with an offset of 1.288 Å (SI 14). There are also two potassium counterions, surrounded by four water molecules. The potassium ions have electrostatic interactions with the carboxylate oxygen, carbonyl oxygen, oxygen atoms of the water molecules, as well as longer contacts with nitrile groups. The nitrile groups are practically linear; the N4-C5-C4 and N2-C2-C1 bond angles are 177.3° and 178.1°, respectively. Extensive and rather complex H-bonding between H2O molecules both coordination water to Ni-centers and outer-sphere crystallization water plays an essential role in organization of the structure (SI 15).

elements.content: This compound also represents a product of hydrolysis of the ester (OEt) group in HECO cyanoxime, in the presence of KOH. The complex crystallizes as a clear, light bronze-brown, needle-like specimen. The crystal and refinement data for this complex are presented in , while selected bond lengths and angles are listed in . This crystal specimen was a four-component rotational twin. Only the first, main domain was used for structure solution/refinement, with details presented in the CIF. The compound K2[Cu3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (3) is isostructural to K2[Ni3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2), and contains a trimeric Cu3 complex (A), very similar to that described above for 2. The bond distances around Cu1 and Cu2 () confirm that they present, respectively, a distorted square-base and an elongated octahedral environment, as the Ni1 and Ni2 centers in compound 2. The Cu2 atom is also in a special position (inversion center), with SOF = 0.5 (SI 16). The C6–O5 and C6–O6 bond lengths (1.275(5) Å and 1.235(5) Å, respectively) are closer to the expected values for C­(sp2)–O, confirming the resonance in the carboxylate anion. The nitrile groups of the oppositely coordinated AACO2– ions to the Cu1 centers have different bond lengths (C5–N4 = 1.134(5) Å and C2–N2 = 1.142(5) Å). The C4–N3 and N3–O4 bond distances (1.300(5) and 1.305(5) Å, respectively) as well as the C1–N1 and N1–O1 (1.308(5) and 1.302(5) Å, respectively), and are all typical of the deprotonated oxime form. The two Cu1 centers are located on parallel planes with an offset of 1.294 Å, as observed in the nickel analogue 2. The dihedral angle between the basal plain of Cu1 and the equatorial plane of Cu2 is 26.38° (SI 16). Because of isostructural nature of Cu complex 3 to the above Ni complex 2, details of the crystal packing for 3 will not be discussed. Again, extensive H-bonding involving all water molecules is essential for the crystal lattice formation and is very similar to that shown for the complex 2. This crystal structure features an extensive 3D network of hydrogen bonds tabulated and is shown in SI 20.

elements.content: Self-standing crystal structure of this complex has been reported by Golenya et al. in 2012, which we found during manuscript preparation. No other characterization of this compound was ever carried out. Also, it turned out that presented in this paper our structural determination of the complex 4 was more accurate. Similar to other compounds reported here, this compound is a hydrolysis product of the HECO cyanoxime ligand that led to the formation of the AACO2– dianion, although, in contrast with 2 and 3, this complex is a monomer. The crystal was obtained as a clear, dark black-purple, prismatic specimen. The crystal and refinement data are shown in , while selected bonds and angles are presented in . This complex contains a dianion formed by a Cu­(II) center connected to two AACO2– anions and one H2O molecule. There are two charge-balancing K+ cations, and two noncoordinated to transition metal water molecules (). The alkali metal cations form rather elegant layers with geometry around them showed in SI 19. The shortest interaction distance between two K2 ions on a side of the molecule with O2 and O4 atoms facing them is 3.992 Å, while the shortest K+ cyanoxime dianion distances are between K1 and O1­(nitroso) and K1---O5­(carboxyl) groups at 2.894 and 2.883 Å respectively. The AACO2– ions are coordinated to the metal ion using the nitrogen atoms of the nitroso groups (N1 and N3) and the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups (O2 and O5), forming an unexpected trans-complex in contrast to complexes 2 and 3. The AACO2– ions adopt a trans-anti-conformation, as in 2 and 3. The Cu­(II) ion has a trans-CuN2O2 basal plane, with an axial water molecule, to form a distorted square-pyramidal coordination geometry ().

elements.content: The basal bond lengths (in the range 1.939–2.002 Å, ) are shorter than the axial one (2.2141 Å). Upon analysis of the unit cell content and packing of 4 into the crystal, it was found that the two square-pyramidal units of [Cu­(AACO)2(H2O)]2– are closely spaced in a back-to-back fashion (SI 17). The bases of pyramids facing each other at a distance of 3.057 Å are coplanar, and being joined by K2+ cations form a “sandwich” with related via inversion center components having the Cu1---Cu1 distance of 3.535 Å (, SI 18).

elements.content: The O2 atom of carboxylic group in one [Cu­(AACO)2­(H2O)]2– unit is located directly under the Cu1 atom of a symmetry related second unit at a distance of 3.174 Å, while the bond length Cu1–O1w in the square pyramid is 2.214 Å (). Both pyramids are slipped against each other with a sidewise offset between Cu1 centers at 1.939 Å. The angle O1w–Cu1–O2 is 162.52°. The Cu1 atom is slightly off the basal N1O2N3O5 plane toward O1w molecule on 0.136 Å. The water molecule O1w is tilted toward K1 cation with the angle of 86.9° (SI 18). As in other presented in this study structures, three independent water molecules O1w, O2w, and O3w play a key role in the organization of the crystal lattice via a complex system of H-bonding (SI 19). The structure forms an extensive network of hydrogen bonds being tabulated in SI 20.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of all compounds showed a stepwise decomposition with the elimination of water molecules in several steps (, SI 21, 22). Data correlate with results of the X-ray analysis evidencing different types of water, H-bonded to the ligand, and coordinated to the transition metal centers. Products of anaerobic (pure N2 atmosphere) decomposition are different; copper complexes converted to elemental Cu that appears as microdroplets in the crucible (, SI 23), while nickel complexes ended up as a mixture of K2O and NiO.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis Data

Thermogravimetric analyses of all compounds showed a stepwise decomposition with the elimination of water molecules in several steps (, SI 21, 22). Data correlate with results of the X-ray analysis evidencing different types of water, H-bonded to the ligand, and coordinated to the transition metal centers. Products of anaerobic (pure N2 atmosphere) decomposition are different; copper complexes converted to elemental Cu that appears as microdroplets in the crucible (, SI 23), while nickel complexes ended up as a mixture of K2O and NiO.

elements.content: Fragment of the thermogravimetric analysis traces of 3 in the range 20–500 °C, showing violent decomposition at ∼200 °C, highlighted in a red oval. Low panels show microscope photographs of the alumina crucibles content, before and after the heating process, under pure N2 gas protection. A visible crack and traces of elemental copper can be observed in the crucible.

A visible crack and traces of elemental copper can be observed in the crucible.

elements.content: The most interesting and unexpected finding during thermal analyses characterization was the discovery of a high-energy potential for both Cu-based complexes, 3 and 4. Thus, when samples of these complexes were heated at a routine default rate of 20 °C/min, after the loss of water molecules a very violent decomposition of anhydrous complexes takes place (). This process takes place above 190 °C. Even at the rate of heating of 10 °C/min, the energy of a rapid decomposition is so high that it implies displacement of the crucibles from the balances and expulsion of the crucible lid. This fast, and rather violent, reaction is accompanied by emptying of the crucible and almost total loss of the substance, with only small amounts of metallic copper remaining deposited on the walls (, SI 8).

Thus, when samples of these complexes were heated at a routine default rate of 20 °C/min, after the loss of water molecules a very violent decomposition of anhydrous complexes takes place (). This process takes place above 190 °C. Even at the rate of heating of 10 °C/min, the energy of a rapid decomposition is so high that it implies displacement of the crucibles from the balances and expulsion of the crucible lid. This fast, and rather violent, reaction is accompanied by emptying of the crucible and almost total loss of the substance, with only small amounts of metallic copper remaining deposited on the walls (, SI 8).

elements.content: At heating rates of 1–5 °C/min, the complexes decompose in a controlled way, with a strong exothermic effect (SI 24–27). The whole process takes a very short time, of ∼5 s for the 20 °C/min rate! (SI 28). An apparent increase of the sample weight during such short and energetic decomposition is attributed to the recoil from the sample to the crucible bottom during such a violent reaction. These complexes can be potentially developed and applied as heat-activated temperature sensors.

The whole process takes a very short time, of ~5 s for the 20 °C/min rate! (SI 28). An apparent increase of the sample weight during such short and energetic decomposition is attributed to the recoil from the sample to the crucible bottom during such a violent reaction. These complexes can be potentially developed and applied as heat-activated temperature sensors.

elements.content: Overlaid spectra of all synthesized compounds are presented in SI 29, while data for selected assigned bands are summarized in . The presence of water molecules leads to very broad bands of ν­(OH) vibrations above 3100 cm–1 due to extensive H-bonding in these systems, as was confirmed by the X-ray analysis presented above. Aside from an expected low-frequency shift for the carboxylic group coordinated to the transition metal, there is also a redistribution of electron density in the C–N–O fragment of the cyanoxime. It is reflected in the rising of the ν­(N–O) frequency and lowering of the ν­(CN) frequency, since the fragment attained more nitroso- character, as opposed to the oxime group (). Similar changes have previously been observed in complexes of other cyanoximes.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Studies

IR Spectra

Overlaid spectra of all synthesized compounds are presented in SI 29, while data for selected assigned bands are summarized in . The presence of water molecules leads to very broad bands of ν(OH) vibrations above 3100 cm-1 due to extensive H-bonding in these systems, as was confirmed by the X-ray analysis presented above. Aside from an expected low-frequency shift for the carboxylic group coordinated to the transition metal, there is also a redistribution of electron density in the C-N-O fragment of the cyanoxime. It is reflected in the rising of the ν(N-O) frequency and lowering of the ν(CN) frequency, since the fragment attained more nitroso- character, as opposed to the oxime group (). Similar changes have previously been observed in complexes of other cyanoximes.

The solid-state reflectance spectra of complexes 2–4 are shown in . The deconvolution of the electronic spectrum of 2 revealed six bands (beyond the visible into the near IR and UV bands inclusive) (SI 30). There are two types of environments around the Ni metal ion in the crystal structure of K2[Ni3(AACO)4­(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2). The first environment has Ni in a distorted octahedral environment with six O atoms. The Ni–O bond lengths in the equatorial positions are not equal; only the Ni–O bonds, trans to each other, are equal. The axial Ni–O bond lengths are equal. Thus, the symmetry point group of the structure around this Ni center is D 2h . The second Ni atom is in a distorted square pyramidal environment, with two N and O atoms correspondingly attached in cis-position at the base, and a water molecule attached apically. The Ni–O and Ni–N bond lengths are not equal, which leads to rhombic distortion. There are no symmetry elements in this metal center, and, thus, the point group is C 1. The d-orbital splitting of Ni in the D 2h environment is as shown in SI 30. The ground state is a 3 A 1g , the first excited state is 3 B 1g , the second excited state is 3 B 3g , and the third excited state is 3 B 2g . Thus, the bands at 990 nm (ca. 10098 cm–1), 680 nm (ca. 14696 cm–1) and 615 nm (ca. 16247 cm–1) can be assigned to the 3 B 1g ← 3 A 1g , 3 B 3g ← 3 A 1g and 3 B 2g ← 3 A 1g transitions, respectively (SI 30). The bands at 325 nm (ca. 30 741 cm–1), 449 nm (ca. 22 245 cm–1), and the prospected band at 252 nm (ca. 39 526 cm–1) can be assigned as π → π*, n → π* in the NO-chromophore, and π → π* in the CN group, respectively. Compound K2[Cu­(AACO)2(H2O)]­·2H2O (4) was treated with a good approximation as having C 2v symmetry point group with the full line shape analysis for both complexes 3 and 4 presented in SI 31, 32. The bands at ca. 15333, 20132, 22335, and 29233 cm–1, could be assigned to the metal-centered 2 A 1 ← 2 A 1 (d z 2 ← d x 2 –y 2 ), 2 B 2 ← 2 A 1, 2 B 1 ← 2 A 1, 2 A 2 ← 2 A 1 transitions, whereas the bands at ca. 33 594 and 38 350 cm–1 are assigned to intraligand n → π* and π → π* transitions, respectively.

Electronic Spectra

The solid-state reflectance spectra of complexes 2-4 are shown in . The deconvolution of the electronic spectrum of 2 revealed six bands (beyond the visible into the near IR and UV bands inclusive) (SI 30). There are two types of environments around the Ni metal ion in the crystal structure of K2[Ni3(AACO)4(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2). The first environment has Ni in a distorted octahedral environment with six O atoms. The Ni-O bond lengths in the equatorial positions are not equal; only the Ni-O bonds, trans to each other, are equal. The axial Ni-O bond lengths are equal. Thus, the symmetry point group of the structure around this Ni center is D 2h . The second Ni atom is in a distorted square pyramidal environment, with two N and O atoms correspondingly attached in cis-position at the base, and a water molecule attached apically. The Ni-O and Ni-N bond lengths are not equal, which leads to rhombic distortion. There are no symmetry elements in this metal center, and, thus, the point group is C 1. The d-orbital splitting of Ni in the D 2h  environment is as shown in SI 30. The ground state is a 3 A 1g , the first excited state is 3 B 1g , the second excited state is 3 B 3g , and the third excited state is 3 B 2g . Thus, the bands at 990 nm (ca. 10098 cm-1), 680 nm (ca. 14696 cm-1) and 615 nm (ca. 16247 cm-1) can be assigned to the 3 B 1g  ← 3 A 1g , 3 B 3g  ← 3 A 1g  and 3 B 2g  ← 3 A 1g  transitions, respectively (SI 30). The bands at 325 nm (ca. 30741 cm-1), 449 nm (ca. 22245 cm-1), and the prospected band at 252 nm (ca. 39526 cm-1) can be assigned as π → π*, n → π* in the NO-chromophore, and π → π* in the CN group, respectively. Compound K2[Cu(AACO)2(H2O)]⋅2H2O (4) was treated with a good approximation as having C 2v  symmetry point group with the full line shape analysis for both complexes 3 and 4 presented in SI 31, 32. The bands at ca. 15333, 20132, 22335, and 29233 cm-1, could be assigned to the metal-centered 2 A 1 ← 2 A 1 (d  z 2  ← d  x   2   -y   2 ), 2 B 2 ← 2 A 1, 2 B 1 ← 2 A 1, 2 A 2 ← 2 A 1 transitions, whereas the bands at ca. 33594 and 38350 cm-1 are assigned to intraligand n → π* and π → π* transitions, respectively.

elements.content: Since crystallographic studies revealed 3D-polymeric structures of polynuclear Cu and Ni complexes with bridging cyanoximate moieties, it was important to investigate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. As was stated above in the introduction, an understanding of origin of such interactions and ability to control them is one of the driving forces behind exploration of coordination polymeric Werner-type paramagnetic complexes. In our case of preparation of polymetallic complexes 1–3 we performed detailed magnetochemical studies of complexes 1 and 3. The mononuclear Cu-complex 4 demonstrated in the solid state rather unusual structure with two slipped base-to-base square-pyramids held together via electrostatic contacts by two nearest K+ counter cations. Observed here fairly close (∼3.5 Å) intermetallic separations, similar to those for other paddle-wheel Cu complexes, warranted thermomagnetic examination of the complex 4.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Since crystallographic studies revealed 3D-polymeric structures of polynuclear Cu and Ni complexes with bridging cyanoximate moieties, it was important to investigate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. As was stated above in the introduction, an understanding of origin of such interactions and ability to control them is one of the driving forces behind exploration of coordination polymeric Werner-type paramagnetic complexes. In our case of preparation of polymetallic complexes 1-3 we performed detailed magnetochemical studies of complexes 1 and 3. The mononuclear Cu-complex 4 demonstrated in the solid state rather unusual structure with two slipped base-to-base square-pyramids held together via electrostatic contacts by two nearest K+ counter cations. Observed here fairly close (~3.5 Å) intermetallic separations, similar to those for other paddle-wheel Cu complexes, warranted thermomagnetic examination of the complex 4.

elements.content: The χm T value at room temperature (ca. 2.2 cm3 K mol–1) is close to the one expected for two isolated S = 1 Ni­(II) ions. When the sample is cooled, χm T decreases to reach a value close to 0 at low temperatures (). This behavior suggests the presence of a moderate/strong AF coupling between the two Ni­(II) ions in the dimer. Accordingly, we have fitted the magnetic properties to an antiferromagnetic S = 1 dimer model with a paramagnetic monomeric impurity, to account for the very small χm T value observed at very low temperatures. This model fits the magnetic properties in the whole temperature range very well, with g = 2.256, an intradimer exchange coupling J = −37.6 cm–1, and a weak paramagnetic impurity c = 1.3%, which accounts for the low χm T value at low temperatures (corresponding to the increase in χm at very low temperatures, , inset) (the Hamiltonian is written as H = −J(S 1 S 2), solid line in ).

elements.content: The χm T value at room temperature (ca. 0.56 cm3 K mol–1) is well below the one expected for three S = 1/2 Cu­(II) ions (ca. 1.125 cm3 Kmol–1), suggesting the presence of a strong Cu–Cu antiferromagnetic (AF) coupling in 3 (). Below ca. 150 K, the χm T value reaches a plateau at ca. 0.45 cm3 K mol–1. This behavior is typical for a linear AF trimer, with a S = 1/2 spin ground state arising from the AF coupling of the central ion with the two terminal ones. Accordingly, we have fitted the magnetic properties to a linear S = 1/2 trimer model with a weak intertrimer interaction, to account for the smooth decrease observed at very low temperatures. This model fits the magnetic properties in the whole temperature range quite well, with g = 2.216, an intratrimer exchange coupling J = −487 cm–1, and a weak AF intertrimer exchange coupling zj = −0.2 cm–1 (the Hamiltonian is written as H = −J(S 1 S 2 + S 2 S 3), the solid line in ).

elements.content: Detailed analysis of the intermolecular dimer (“sandwich”) in the structure of 4 evidenced the possibility for Cu---Cu interactions similar to those in famous Cu-paddle-wheel carboxylates (). The χm T value at room temperature (ca. 0.32 cm3 K mol–1) is slightly below the one expected for one S = 1/2 Cu­(II) ion (ca. 0.375 cm3 K mol–1) (). This indicates that the sample may contain some diamagnetic impurities (as Cu­(I) or the K+ salt of the ligand). The χm T value remains constant down to very low temperatures, indicating the absence of any significant intercopper interactions and isolated status for the Cu­(II) centers. The closest distance between copper­(II) centers was 3.535 Å, which is on a longer side of observed magnetically coupled atoms. However, it has been established for some time that the intermetallic distance is not the only important parameter for the exchange since it varies significantly in coupled systems. In our case most likely is a sidewise offset of 1.939 Å from a direct base-to-base alignment between the two pyramids (). This misalignment resulted in considerable angular distortions in the interunits dimer that made d-orbitals interactions very unlikely. It was manifested in the absence of magnetic coupling between two Cu-centers which act as being isolated.

elements.content:
A new in situ method for the synthesis of Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) complexes of cyano-hydroxyimino-acetate dianion (AACO2–) was found. Previously, direct interaction between the H2AACO cyanoxime and its dianion did not lead to polymetallic complexes, which demonstrates the utility of our approach for synthetic coordination chemistry.

Four nickel and copper complexes were obtained and characterized using a variety of techniques and methods. A side reaction byproduct of the ester-cyanoximes hydrolysis reactionsoxamidewas identified as well. The route to this unusual product has been suggested.

The crystal structure of a new, low temperature, polymorph, of one of the precursors, ethyl-cyanoacetate oxime (HECO), was determined.

In the three polynuclear metal complexes (1–3), the AACO2– dianion acts as a bridging ligand connecting different metal centers via the C–N–O fragment. These polynuclear metal complexes show moderate antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers.

The two copper­(II) complexes (3 and 4) were found to have properties of high-energy compounds, which, after losing crystallization water, violently decompose, with release of significant kinetic energy and formation of elemental Cu. These reactions are heat rate dependent, and as such, complexes 3 and 4 can be used as room temperature safe, but heat-triggered actuators.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

   A new in situ method for the synthesis of Ni(II) and Cu(II) complexes of cyano-hydroxyimino-acetate dianion (AACO2-) was found. Previously, direct interaction between the H2AACO cyanoxime and its dianion did not lead to polymetallic complexes, which demonstrates the utility of our approach for synthetic coordination chemistry.   Four nickel and copper complexes were obtained and characterized using a variety of techniques and methods. A side reaction byproduct of the ester-cyanoximes hydrolysis reactionsoxamidewas identified as well. The route to this unusual product has been suggested.   The crystal structure of a new, low temperature, polymorph, of one of the precursors, ethyl-cyanoacetate oxime (HECO), was determined.   In the three polynuclear metal complexes (1-3), the AACO2- dianion acts as a bridging ligand connecting different metal centers via the C-N-O fragment. These polynuclear metal complexes show moderate antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers.   The two copper(II) complexes (3 and 4) were found to have properties of high-energy compounds, which, after losing crystallization water, violently decompose, with release of significant kinetic energy and formation of elemental Cu. These reactions are heat rate dependent, and as such, complexes 3 and 4 can be used as room temperature safe, but heat-triggered actuators.

cln_elements.content:
Glacial acetic acid (100 mL) and NaOH pellets (12 g) were placed in a 500 mL three-neck round-bottom flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer and a long stem funnel, under intense stirring. Within ∼10 min, pellets of hydroxide dissolved, evolving heat and bringing the mixture to reflux. Methyl cyanoacetate (50.0 g, 0.50 mol) was added to this hot solution, and slow dropwise addition of a solution of NaNO2 (80 g, 1.16 mol) in water (100 mL) began immediately. The addition was complete within 1–1.5 h, but the stirring continued until the reaction mixture temperature dropped to ∼+25 °C, and then continued for an additional 3 h, until the precipitate of the cyanoxime began to form. Then the mixture was diluted with water (100 mL) and allowed to stand at +4 °C for another 3 h. Bulk solid precipitate was collected by vacuum filtration and dried in air to give microcrystalline off-white product. Yield: ∼90%.

Target cyanoxime ligand was prepared by reacting 5.700 g (82.6 mM) of NaNO2 dissolved in 75 mL of H2O with 10.000 g (88.4 mM) of ethyl cyanoacetate in a round-bottom flask, according to the reaction in . Then 3.6 mL of 1 M H3PO4 was added to the reaction mixture, dropwise over 45 min, and the temperature was kept at +3–4 °C using an ice bath. After the addition of 1 M H3PO4 was completed, the temperature was raised to +40 °C, and the reaction was quenched with 7.3 mL of fuming HCl at +65 °C. The mixture was left to cool to room temperature. The reaction mixture was then kept in the refrigerator for a period of approximately 11 h. The mixture was filtered using filter paper and gravity filtration. The precipitate was dried in a vacuum. The filtrate was extracted with ethyl acetate after the mixture was treated with solid NaCl to facilitate extraction. The solution was off-yellow, and the color was maintained in the organic phase, while the aqueous phase was colorless. The dried precipitate was 7.153 g. An additional amount of 3.042 g was obtained after the extraction. The total yield of HECO was 10.195 g (81%); m.p = 129.4–132.4 °C.

Preparation of Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) AACO<sup>2–</sup> Dianion Complex Using the HECO Ligand

Two separate solutions of HECO were prepared separately, in two 25 mL beakers, by dissolving 0.300 g (2.11 mmol) of the HECO ligand in 5 mL of H2O. Then 2.11 mL (2.11 mmol) of 1 M KOH solution was added to each of the HECO solutions in the beakers for the deprotonation of the HECO ligand (). The color of the solution changed to deep yellow. The solutions were stirred continuously using magnetic stirrers. Then 0.3069 g (1.06 mM) of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.1685 g (1.06 mmol) of CuSO4·5H2O, were dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water in another two separate beakers, and these solutions were added in, dropwise, separately to the beakers containing the deprotonated ECO– ligand solutions. A clear deep brown solution was formed in the beaker to which the Ni­(II) salt was added, and green solution was formed in the beaker to which the Cu­(II) salt was added. The solutions were allowed to stand for ∼2 h, under continuous stirring at room temperature. No precipitates were formed. The clear deep brown solution and green solutions were filtered through a tight glass wool plug into clear 10 mL capacity polyethylene test tubes where crystals eventually appeared in abundance. For future convenient identification and use of the obtained metal complexes, we refer to , which contains compounds’ abbreviations employed in this paper. We did not feel the necessity of obtaining their elemental composition data since all characterization of the obtained four metal complexes as well as one the initial cyanoxime ligands (HECO) and the side reaction product oxamide was done using those crystalline samples structures of which have been determined. All other investigationsspectroscopic, magnetochemical and thermogravimetricwere conducted from the same well-crystallized specimen (see Supporting Information SI 1, 2).
